list.item: DUKE OF MILAN Father to Silvia.
THURIO a foolish rival to Valentine.
EGLAMOUR Agent for Silvia in her escape.
SPEED a clownish servant to Valentine.

p.stage: Scene: Verona; Milan; the frontiers of Mantua.

sp.speaker: VALENTINE
sp.p:
Cease to persuade, my loving Proteus:
Home-keeping youth have ever homely wits.
Were't not affection chains thy tender days
To the sweet glances of thy honour'd love,
I rather would entreat thy company
To see the wonders of the world abroad,
Than, living dully sluggardized at home,
Wear out thy youth with shapeless idleness.
But since thou lovest, love still and thrive therein,
Even as I would when I to love begin.

sp.speaker: PROTEUS
sp.p:
Wilt thou be gone? Sweet Valentine, adieu!
Think on thy Proteus, when thou haply seest
Some rare note-worthy object in thy travel:
Wish me partaker in thy happiness
When thou dost meet good hap; and in thy danger,
If ever danger do environ thee,
Commend thy grievance to my holy prayers,
For I will be thy beadsman, Valentine.

sp.speaker: VALENTINE
sp.p: And on a love-book pray for my success?

sp.speaker: PROTEUS
sp.p: Upon some book I love I'll pray for thee.

sp.speaker: VALENTINE
sp.p:
That's on some shallow story of deep love:
How young Leander cross'd the Hellespont.

sp.speaker: PROTEUS
sp.p:
That's a deep story of a deeper love:
For he was more than over shoes in love.

sp.speaker: VALENTINE
sp.p:
'Tis true; for you are over boots in love,
And yet you never swum the Hellespont.

sp.speaker: PROTEUS
sp.p: Over the boots? nay, give me not the boots.

sp.speaker: VALENTINE
sp.p: No, I will not, for it boots thee not.

sp.speaker: PROTEUS
sp.p: What?

sp.speaker: VALENTINE
PROTEUS
sp.p: So, by your circumstance, you call me fool.

sp.speaker: VALENTINE
sp.p: So, by your circumstance, I fear you'll prove.

sp.speaker: PROTEUS
sp.p: 'Tis love you cavil at: I am not Love.

sp.speaker: VALENTINE
sp.p:
Love is your master, for he masters you:
And he that is so yoked by a fool,
Methinks, should not be chronicled for wise.

sp.speaker: PROTEUS
sp.p:
Yet writers say, as in the sweetest bud
The eating canker dwells, so eating love
Inhabits in the finest wits of all.

sp.speaker: VALENTINE
sp.p:
And writers say, as the most forward bud
Is eaten by the canker ere it blow,
Even so by love the young and tender wit
Is turn'd to folly, blasting in the bud,
Losing his verdure even in the prime
And all the fair effects of future hopes.
But wherefore waste I time to counsel thee,
That art a votary to fond desire?
Once more adieu! my father at the road
Expects my coming, there to see me shipp'd.

sp.speaker: PROTEUS
sp.p: And thither will I bring thee, Valentine.

sp.speaker: VALENTINE
sp.p:
Sweet Proteus, no; now let us take our leave.
To Milan let me hear from thee by letters
Of thy success in love, and what news else
Betideth here in absence of thy friend;
And likewise will visit thee with mine.

sp.speaker: PROTEUS
sp.p: All happiness bechance to thee in Milan!

sp.speaker: VALENTINE
sp.p: As much to you at home! and so, farewell.

sp.speaker: PROTEUS
sp.p:
He after honour hunts, I after love:
He leaves his friends to dignify them more,
I leave myself, my friends and all, for love.
Thou, Julia, thou hast metamorphosed me,
Made me neglect my studies, lose my time,
War with good counsel, set the world at nought;
Made wit with musing weak, heart sick with thought.

sp.speaker: SPEED
sp.p: Sir Proteus, save you! Saw you my master?

sp.speaker: PROTEUS
sp.p: But now he parted hence, to embark for Milan.

sp.speaker: SPEED
sp.p:
Twenty to one then he is shipp'd already,
And I have play'd the sheep in losing him.

sp.speaker: PROTEUS
sp.p:
Indeed, a sheep doth very often stray,
An if the shepherd be a while away.

sp.speaker: SPEED
sp.p:
You conclude that my master is a shepherd, then,
and I a sheep?

sp.speaker: PROTEUS
sp.p: I do.

sp.speaker: SPEED
sp.p: Why then, my horns are his horns, whether I wake or sleep.

sp.speaker: PROTEUS
sp.p: A silly answer and fitting well a sheep.

sp.speaker: SPEED
sp.p: This proves me still a sheep.

sp.speaker: PROTEUS
sp.p: True; and thy master a shepherd.

sp.speaker: SPEED
sp.p: Nay, that I can deny by a circumstance.

sp.speaker: PROTEUS
sp.p: It shall go hard but I'll prove it by another.

sp.speaker: SPEED
sp.p:
The shepherd seeks the sheep, and not the sheep the
shepherd; but I seek my master, and my master seeks
not me: therefore I am no sheep.

sp.speaker: PROTEUS
sp.p:
The sheep for fodder follow the shepherd; the
shepherd for food follows not the sheep: thou for
wages followest thy master; thy master for wages
follows not thee: therefore thou art a sheep.

sp.speaker: SPEED
sp.p: Such another proof will make me cry 'baa.'

sp.speaker: PROTEUS
sp.p: But, dost thou hear? gavest thou my letter to Julia?

sp.speaker: SPEED
sp.p:
Ay sir: I, a lost mutton, gave your letter to her,
a laced mutton, and she, a laced mutton, gave me, a
lost mutton, nothing for my labour.

sp.speaker: PROTEUS
sp.p: Here's too small a pasture for such store of muttons.

sp.speaker: SPEED
sp.p: If the ground be overcharged, you were best stick her.

sp.speaker: PROTEUS
sp.p: Nay: in that you are astray, 'twere best pound you.

sp.speaker: SPEED
sp.p:
Nay, sir, less than a pound shall serve me for
carrying your letter.

sp.speaker: PROTEUS
sp.p: You mistake; I mean the pound,—a pinfold.

sp.speaker: SPEED
sp.p:
From a pound to a pin? fold it over and over,
'Tis threefold too little for carrying a letter to
your lover.

sp.speaker: PROTEUS
sp.p: But what said she?

sp.speaker: SPEED
sp.p: Ay.

sp.speaker: PROTEUS
sp.p: Nod—Ay—why, that's noddy.

sp.speaker: SPEED
sp.p:
You mistook, sir; I say, she did nod: and you ask
me if she did nod; and I say, 'Ay.'

sp.speaker: PROTEUS
sp.p: And that set together is noddy.

sp.speaker: SPEED
sp.p:
Now you have taken the pains to set it together,
take it for your pains.

sp.speaker: PROTEUS
sp.p: No, no; you shall have it for bearing the letter.

sp.speaker: SPEED
sp.p: Well, I perceive I must be fain to bear with you.

sp.speaker: PROTEUS
sp.p: Why sir, how do you bear with me?

sp.speaker: SPEED
sp.p:
Marry, sir, the letter, very orderly; having nothing
but the word 'noddy' for my pains.

sp.speaker: PROTEUS
sp.p: Beshrew me, but you have a quick wit.

sp.speaker: SPEED
sp.p: And yet it cannot overtake your slow purse.

sp.speaker: PROTEUS
sp.p: Come come, open the matter in brief: what said she?

sp.speaker: SPEED
sp.p:
Open your purse, that the money and the matter may
be both at once delivered.

sp.speaker: PROTEUS
sp.p: Well, sir, here is for your pains. What said she?

sp.speaker: SPEED
sp.p: Truly, sir, I think you'll hardly win her.

sp.speaker: PROTEUS
sp.p: Why, couldst thou perceive so much from her?

sp.speaker: SPEED
sp.p:
Sir, I could perceive nothing at all from her; no,
not so much as a ducat for delivering your letter:
and being so hard to me that brought your mind, I
fear she'll prove as hard to you in telling your
mind. Give her no token but stones; for she's as
hard as steel.

sp.speaker: PROTEUS
sp.p: What said she? nothing?

sp.speaker: SPEED
sp.p:
No, not so much as 'Take this for thy pains.' To
testify your bounty, I thank you, you have testerned
me; in requital whereof, henceforth carry your
letters yourself: and so, sir, I'll commend you to my master.

sp.speaker: PROTEUS
sp.p:
Go, go, be gone, to save your ship from wreck,
Which cannot perish having thee aboard,
Being destined to a drier death on shore.

I must go send some better messenger:
I fear my Julia would not deign my lines,
Receiving them from such a worthless post.

p.stage: The same. Garden of JULIA's house.

sp.speaker: JULIA
sp.p:
But say, Lucetta, now we are alone,
Wouldst thou then counsel me to fall in love?

sp.speaker: LUCETTA
sp.p: Ay, madam, so you stumble not unheedfully.

sp.speaker: JULIA
sp.p:
Of all the fair resort of gentlemen
That every day with parle encounter me,
In thy opinion which is worthiest love?

sp.speaker: LUCETTA
sp.p:
Please you repeat their names, I'll show my mind
According to my shallow simple skill.

sp.speaker: JULIA
sp.p: What think'st thou of the fair Sir Eglamour?

sp.speaker: LUCETTA
sp.p:
As of a knight well-spoken, neat and fine;
But, were I you, he never should be mine.

sp.speaker: JULIA
sp.p: What think'st thou of the rich Mercatio?

sp.speaker: LUCETTA
sp.p: Well of his wealth; but of himself, so so.

sp.speaker: JULIA
sp.p: What think'st thou of the gentle Proteus?

sp.speaker: LUCETTA
sp.p: Lord, Lord! to see what folly reigns in us!

sp.speaker: JULIA
sp.p: How now! what means this passion at his name?

sp.speaker: LUCETTA
sp.p:
Pardon, dear madam: 'tis a passing shame
That I, unworthy body as I am,
Should censure thus on lovely gentlemen.

sp.speaker: JULIA
sp.p: Why not on Proteus, as of all the rest?

sp.speaker: LUCETTA
sp.p: Then thus: of many good I think him best.

sp.speaker: JULIA
sp.p: Your reason?

sp.speaker: LUCETTA
sp.p:
I have no other, but a woman's reason;
I think him so because I think him so.

sp.speaker: JULIA
sp.p: And wouldst thou have me cast my love on him?

sp.speaker: LUCETTA
sp.p: Ay, if you thought your love not cast away.

sp.speaker: JULIA
sp.p: Why he, of all the rest, hath never moved me.

sp.speaker: LUCETTA
sp.p: Yet he, of all the rest, I think, best loves ye.

sp.speaker: JULIA
sp.p: His little speaking shows his love but small.

sp.speaker: LUCETTA
sp.p: Fire that's closest kept burns most of all.

sp.speaker: JULIA
sp.p: They do not love that do not show their love.

sp.speaker: LUCETTA
sp.p: O, they love least that let men know their love.

sp.speaker: JULIA
sp.p: I would I knew his mind.

sp.speaker: LUCETTA
sp.p: Peruse this paper, madam.

sp.speaker: JULIA
sp.p: 'To Julia.' Say, from whom?

sp.speaker: LUCETTA
sp.p: That the contents will show.

sp.speaker: JULIA
sp.p: Say, say, who gave it thee?

sp.speaker: LUCETTA
sp.p:
Valentine's page; and sent, I think, from Proteus.
He would have given it you; but I, being in the way,
Did in your name receive it: pardon the
fault I pray.

sp.speaker: JULIA
sp.p:
Now, by my modesty, a goodly broker!
Dare you presume to harbour wanton lines?
To whisper and conspire against my youth?
Now, trust me, 'tis an office of great worth
And you an officer fit for the place.
Or else return no more into my sight.

sp.speaker: LUCETTA
sp.p: To plead for love deserves more fee than hate.

sp.speaker: JULIA
sp.p: Will ye be gone?

sp.speaker: LUCETTA
sp.p: That you may ruminate.

sp.speaker: JULIA
sp.p:
And yet I would I had o'erlooked the letter:
It were a shame to call her back again
And pray her to a fault for which I chid her.
What a fool is she, that knows I am a maid,
And would not force the letter to my view!
Since maids, in modesty, say 'no' to that
Which they would have the profferer construe 'ay.'
Fie, fie, how wayward is this foolish love
That, like a testy babe, will scratch the nurse
And presently all humbled kiss the rod!
How churlishly I chid Lucetta hence,
When willingly I would have had her here!
How angerly I taught my brow to frown,
When inward joy enforced my heart to smile!
My penance is to call Lucetta back
And ask remission for my folly past.
What ho! Lucetta!

sp.speaker: LUCETTA
sp.p: What would your ladyship?

sp.speaker: JULIA
sp.p: Is't near dinner-time?

sp.speaker: LUCETTA
sp.p:
I would it were,
That you might kill your stomach on your meat
And not upon your maid.

sp.speaker: JULIA
sp.p: What is't that you took up so gingerly?

sp.speaker: LUCETTA
sp.p: Nothing.

sp.speaker: JULIA
sp.p: Why didst thou stoop, then?

sp.speaker: LUCETTA
sp.p: To take a paper up that I let fall.

sp.speaker: JULIA
sp.p: And is that paper nothing?

sp.speaker: LUCETTA
sp.p: Nothing concerning me.

sp.speaker: JULIA
sp.p: Then let it lie for those that it concerns.

sp.speaker: LUCETTA
sp.p:
Madam, it will not lie where it concerns
Unless it have a false interpeter.

sp.speaker: JULIA
sp.p: Some love of yours hath writ to you in rhyme.

sp.speaker: LUCETTA
sp.p:
That I might sing it, madam, to a tune.
Give me a note: your ladyship can set.

sp.speaker: JULIA
sp.p:
As little by such toys as may be possible.
Best sing it to the tune of 'Light o' love.'

sp.speaker: LUCETTA
sp.p: It is too heavy for so light a tune.

sp.speaker: JULIA
sp.p: Heavy! belike it hath some burden then?

sp.speaker: LUCETTA
sp.p: Ay, and melodious were it, would you sing it.

sp.speaker: JULIA
sp.p: And why not you?

sp.speaker: LUCETTA
sp.p: I cannot reach so high.

sp.speaker: JULIA
sp.p: Let's see your song. How now, minion!

sp.speaker: LUCETTA
sp.p:
Keep tune there still, so you will sing it out:
And yet methinks I do not like this tune.

sp.speaker: JULIA
sp.p: You do not?

sp.speaker: LUCETTA
sp.p: No, madam; it is too sharp.

sp.speaker: JULIA
sp.p: You, minion, are too saucy.

sp.speaker: LUCETTA
sp.p:
Nay, now you are too flat
And mar the concord with too harsh a descant:
There wanteth but a mean to fill your song.

sp.speaker: JULIA
sp.p: The mean is drown'd with your unruly bass.

sp.speaker: LUCETTA
sp.p: Indeed, I bid the base for Proteus.

sp.speaker: JULIA
sp.p:
This babble shall not henceforth trouble me.
Here is a coil with protestation!

Go get you gone, and let the papers lie:
You would be fingering them, to anger me.

sp.speaker: LUCETTA
sp.p:
She makes it strange; but she would be best pleased
To be so anger'd with another letter.

sp.speaker: JULIA
sp.p:
Nay, would I were so anger'd with the same!
O hateful hands, to tear such loving words!
Injurious wasps, to feed on such sweet honey
And kill the bees that yield it with your stings!
I'll kiss each several paper for amends.
Look, here is writ 'kind Julia.' Unkind Julia!
As in revenge of thy ingratitude,
I throw thy name against the bruising stones,
Trampling contemptuously on thy disdain.
And here is writ 'love-wounded Proteus.'
Poor wounded name! my bosom as a bed
Shall lodge thee till thy wound be thoroughly heal'd;
And thus I search it with a sovereign kiss.
But twice or thrice was 'Proteus' written down.
Be calm, good wind, blow not a word away
Till I have found each letter in the letter,
Except mine own name: that some whirlwind bear
Unto a ragged fearful-hanging rock
And throw it thence into the raging sea!
Lo, here in one line is his name twice writ,
'Poor forlorn Proteus, passionate Proteus,
To the sweet Julia:' that I'll tear away.
And yet I will not, sith so prettily
He couples it to his complaining names.
Thus will I fold them one on another:
Now kiss, embrace, contend, do what you will.

sp.speaker: LUCETTA
sp.p:
Madam,
Dinner is ready, and your father stays.

sp.speaker: JULIA
sp.p: Well, let us go.

sp.speaker: LUCETTA
sp.p: What, shall these papers lie like tell-tales here?

sp.speaker: JULIA
sp.p: If you respect them, best to take them up.

sp.speaker: LUCETTA
sp.p:
Nay, I was taken up for laying them down:
Yet here they shall not lie, for catching cold.

sp.speaker: JULIA
sp.p: I see you have a month's mind to them.

sp.speaker: LUCETTA
sp.p:
Ay, madam, you may say what sights you see;
I see things too, although you judge I wink.

sp.speaker: JULIA
sp.p: Come, come; will't please you go?

sp.speaker: ANTONIO
sp.p:
Tell me, Panthino, what sad talk was that
Wherewith my brother held you in the cloister?

sp.speaker: PANTHINO
sp.p: 'Twas of his nephew Proteus, your son.

sp.speaker: ANTONIO
sp.p: Why, what of him?

sp.speaker: PANTHINO
sp.p:
He wonder'd that your lordship
Would suffer him to spend his youth at home,
While other men, of slender reputation,
Put forth their sons to seek preferment out:
Some to the wars, to try their fortune there;
Some to discover islands far away;
Some to the studious universities.
For any or for all these exercises,
He said that Proteus your son was meet,
And did request me to importune you
To let him spend his time no more at home,
Which would be great impeachment to his age,
In having known no travel in his youth.

sp.speaker: ANTONIO
sp.p:
Nor need'st thou much importune me to that
Whereon this month I have been hammering.
I have consider'd well his loss of time
And how he cannot be a perfect man,
Not being tried and tutor'd in the world:
Experience is by industry achieved
And perfected by the swift course of time.
Then tell me, whither were I best to send him?

sp.speaker: PANTHINO
sp.p:
I think your lordship is not ignorant
How his companion, youthful Valentine,
Attends the emperor in his royal court.

sp.speaker: ANTONIO
sp.p: I know it well.

sp.speaker: PANTHINO
sp.p:
'Twere good, I think, your lordship sent him thither:
There shall he practise tilts and tournaments,
Hear sweet discourse, converse with noblemen.
And be in eye of every exercise
Worthy his youth and nobleness of birth.

sp.speaker: ANTONIO
sp.p:
I like thy counsel; well hast thou advised:
And that thou mayst perceive how well I like it,
The execution of it shall make known.
Even with the speediest expedition
I will dispatch him to the emperor's court.

sp.speaker: PANTHINO
sp.p:
To-morrow, may it please you, Don Alphonso,
With other gentlemen of good esteem,
Are journeying to salute the emperor
And to commend their service to his will.

sp.speaker: ANTONIO
sp.p:
Good company; with them shall Proteus go:
And, in good time! now will we break with him.

sp.speaker: PROTEUS
sp.p:
Sweet love! sweet lines! sweet life!
Here is her hand, the agent of her heart;
Here is her oath for love, her honour's pawn.
O, that our fathers would applaud our loves,
To seal our happiness with their consents!
O heavenly Julia!

sp.speaker: ANTONIO
sp.p: How now! what letter are you reading there?

sp.speaker: PROTEUS
sp.p:
May't please your lordship, 'tis a word or two
Of commendations sent from Valentine,
Deliver'd by a friend that came from him.

sp.speaker: ANTONIO
sp.p: Lend me the letter; let me see what news.

sp.speaker: PROTEUS
sp.p:
There is no news, my lord, but that he writes
How happily he lives, how well beloved
And daily graced by the emperor;
Wishing me with him, partner of his fortune.

sp.speaker: ANTONIO
sp.p: And how stand you affected to his wish?

sp.speaker: PROTEUS
sp.p:
As one relying on your lordship's will
And not depending on his friendly wish.

sp.speaker: ANTONIO
sp.p:
My will is something sorted with his wish.
Muse not that I thus suddenly proceed;
For what I will, I will, and there an end.
I am resolved that thou shalt spend some time
With Valentinus in the emperor's court:
What maintenance he from his friends receives,
Like exhibition thou shalt have from me.
To-morrow be in readiness to go:
Excuse it not, for I am peremptory.

sp.speaker: PROTEUS
sp.p:
My lord, I cannot be so soon provided:
Please you, deliberate a day or two.

sp.speaker: ANTONIO
sp.p:
Look, what thou want'st shall be sent after thee:
No more of stay! to-morrow thou must go.
Come on, Panthino: you shall be employ'd
To hasten on his expedition.

sp.speaker: PROTEUS
sp.p:
Thus have I shunn'd the fire for fear of burning,
And drench'd me in the sea, where I am drown'd.
I fear'd to show my father Julia's letter,
Lest he should take exceptions to my love;
And with the vantage of mine own excuse
Hath he excepted most against my love.
O, how this spring of love resembleth
The uncertain glory of an April day,
Which now shows all the beauty of the sun,
And by and by a cloud takes all away!

sp.speaker: PANTHINO
sp.p:
Sir Proteus, your father calls for you:
He is in haste; therefore, I pray you to go.

sp.speaker: PROTEUS
sp.p:
Why, this it is: my heart accords thereto,
And yet a thousand times it answers 'no.'

sp.speaker: SPEED
sp.p: Sir, your glove.

sp.speaker: VALENTINE
sp.p: Not mine; my gloves are on.

sp.speaker: SPEED
sp.p: Why, then, this may be yours, for this is but one.

sp.speaker: VALENTINE
sp.p:
Ha! let me see: ay, give it me, it's mine:
Sweet ornament that decks a thing divine!
Ah, Silvia, Silvia!

sp.speaker: SPEED
sp.p: Madam Silvia! Madam Silvia!

sp.speaker: VALENTINE
sp.p: How now, sirrah?

sp.speaker: SPEED
sp.p: She is not within hearing, sir.

sp.speaker: VALENTINE
sp.p: Why, sir, who bade you call her?

sp.speaker: SPEED
sp.p: Your worship, sir; or else I mistook.

sp.speaker: VALENTINE
sp.p: Well, you'll still be too forward.

sp.speaker: SPEED
sp.p: And yet I was last chidden for being too slow.

sp.speaker: VALENTINE
sp.p: Go to, sir: tell me, do you know Madam Silvia?

sp.speaker: SPEED
sp.p: She that your worship loves?

sp.speaker: VALENTINE
sp.p: Why, how know you that I am in love?

sp.speaker: SPEED
sp.p:
Marry, by these special marks: first, you have
learned, like Sir Proteus, to wreathe your arms,
like a malecontent; to relish a love-song, like a
robin-redbreast; to walk alone, like one that had
the pestilence; to sigh, like a school-boy that had
lost his A B C; to weep, like a young wench that had
buried her grandam; to fast, like one that takes
diet; to watch like one that fears robbing; to
speak puling, like a beggar at Hallowmas. You were
wont, when you laughed, to crow like a cock; when you
walked, to walk like one of the lions; when you
fasted, it was presently after dinner; when you
looked sadly, it was for want of money: and now you
are metamorphosed with a mistress, that, when I look
on you, I can hardly think you my master.

sp.speaker: VALENTINE
sp.p: Are all these things perceived in me?

sp.speaker: SPEED
sp.p: They are all perceived without ye.

sp.speaker: VALENTINE
sp.p: Without me? they cannot.

sp.speaker: SPEED
sp.p:
Without you? nay, that's certain, for, without you
were so simple, none else would: but you are so
without these follies, that these follies are within
you and shine through you like the water in an
urinal, that not an eye that sees you but is a
physician to comment on your malady.

sp.speaker: VALENTINE
sp.p: But tell me, dost thou know my lady Silvia?

sp.speaker: SPEED
sp.p: She that you gaze on so as she sits at supper?

sp.speaker: VALENTINE
sp.p: Hast thou observed that? even she, I mean.

sp.speaker: SPEED
sp.p: Why, sir, I know her not.

sp.speaker: VALENTINE
sp.p:
Dost thou know her by my gazing on her, and yet
knowest her not?

sp.speaker: SPEED
sp.p: Is she not hard-favoured, sir?

sp.speaker: VALENTINE
sp.p: Not so fair, boy, as well-favoured.

sp.speaker: SPEED
sp.p: Sir, I know that well enough.

sp.speaker: VALENTINE
sp.p: What dost thou know?

sp.speaker: SPEED
sp.p: That she is not so fair as, of you, well-favoured.

sp.speaker: VALENTINE
sp.p: I mean that her beauty is exquisite, but her favour infinite.

sp.speaker: SPEED
sp.p:
That's because the one is painted and the other out
of all count.

sp.speaker: VALENTINE
sp.p: How painted? and how out of count?

sp.speaker: SPEED
sp.p:
Marry, sir, so painted, to make her fair, that no
man counts of her beauty.

sp.speaker: VALENTINE
sp.p: How esteemest thou me? I account of her beauty.

sp.speaker: SPEED
sp.p: You never saw her since she was deformed.

sp.speaker: VALENTINE
sp.p: How long hath she been deformed?

sp.speaker: SPEED
sp.p: Ever since you loved her.

sp.speaker: VALENTINE
sp.p:
I have loved her ever since I saw her; and still I
see her beautiful.

sp.speaker: SPEED
sp.p: If you love her, you cannot see her.

sp.speaker: VALENTINE
sp.p: Why?

sp.speaker: SPEED
sp.p:
Because Love is blind. O, that you had mine eyes;
or your own eyes had the lights they were wont to
have when you chid at Sir Proteus for going
ungartered!

sp.speaker: VALENTINE
sp.p: What should I see then?

sp.speaker: SPEED
sp.p:
Your own present folly and her passing deformity:
for he, being in love, could not see to garter his
hose, and you, being in love, cannot see to put on your hose.

sp.speaker: VALENTINE
sp.p:
Belike, boy, then, you are in love; for last
morning you could not see to wipe my shoes.

sp.speaker: SPEED
sp.p:
True, sir; I was in love with my bed: I thank you,
you swinged me for my love, which makes me the
bolder to chide you for yours.

sp.speaker: VALENTINE
sp.p: In conclusion, I stand affected to her.

sp.speaker: SPEED
sp.p: I would you were set, so your affection would cease.

sp.speaker: VALENTINE
sp.p:
Last night she enjoined me to write some lines to
one she loves.

sp.speaker: SPEED
sp.p: And have you?

sp.speaker: VALENTINE
sp.p: I have.

sp.speaker: SPEED
sp.p: Are they not lamely writ?

sp.speaker: VALENTINE
sp.p:
No, boy, but as well as I can do them. Peace!
here she comes.

sp.speaker: SPEED
sp.p:
O excellent motion! O exceeding puppet!
Now will he interpret to her.

sp.speaker: VALENTINE
sp.p: Madam and mistress, a thousand good-morrows.

sp.speaker: SPEED
sp.p: O, give ye good even! here's a million of manners.

sp.speaker: SILVIA
sp.p: Sir Valentine and servant, to you two thousand.

sp.speaker: SPEED
sp.p: He should give her interest and she gives it him.

sp.speaker: VALENTINE
sp.p:
As you enjoin'd me, I have writ your letter
Unto the secret nameless friend of yours;
Which I was much unwilling to proceed in
But for my duty to your ladyship.

sp.speaker: SILVIA
sp.p: I thank you gentle servant: 'tis very clerkly done.

sp.speaker: VALENTINE
SILVIA
sp.p: Perchance you think too much of so much pains?

sp.speaker: VALENTINE
sp.p:
No, madam; so it stead you, I will write
Please you command, a thousand times as much; And yet—

sp.speaker: SILVIA
SPEED
sp.p: And yet you will; and yet another 'yet.'

sp.speaker: VALENTINE
sp.p: What means your ladyship? do you not like it?

sp.speaker: SILVIA
VALENTINE
sp.p: Madam, they are for you.

sp.speaker: SILVIA
VALENTINE
sp.p: Please you, I'll write your ladyship another.

sp.speaker: SILVIA
sp.p:
And when it's writ, for my sake read it over,
And if it please you, so; if not, why, so.

sp.speaker: VALENTINE
sp.p: If it please me, madam, what then?

sp.speaker: SILVIA
sp.p:
Why, if it please you, take it for your labour:
And so, good morrow, servant.

sp.speaker: SPEED
sp.p:
O jest unseen, inscrutable, invisible,
As a nose on a man's face, or a weathercock on a steeple!
My master sues to her, and she hath
taught her suitor,
He being her pupil, to become her tutor.
O excellent device! was there ever heard a better,
That my master, being scribe, to himself should write
the letter?

sp.speaker: VALENTINE
sp.p: How now, sir? what are you reasoning with yourself?

sp.speaker: SPEED
sp.p: Nay, I was rhyming: 'tis you that have the reason.

sp.speaker: VALENTINE
sp.p: To do what?

sp.speaker: SPEED
sp.p: To be a spokesman for Madam Silvia.

sp.speaker: VALENTINE
sp.p: To whom?

sp.speaker: SPEED
sp.p: To yourself: why, she wooes you by a figure.

sp.speaker: VALENTINE
sp.p: What figure?

sp.speaker: SPEED
sp.p: By a letter, I should say.

sp.speaker: VALENTINE
sp.p: Why, she hath not writ to me?

sp.speaker: SPEED
sp.p:
What need she, when she hath made you write to
yourself? Why, do you not perceive the jest?

sp.speaker: VALENTINE
sp.p: No, believe me.

sp.speaker: SPEED
sp.p:
No believing you, indeed, sir. But did you perceive
her earnest?

sp.speaker: VALENTINE
sp.p: She gave me none, except an angry word.

sp.speaker: SPEED
sp.p: Why, she hath given you a letter.

sp.speaker: VALENTINE
sp.p: That's the letter I writ to her friend.

sp.speaker: SPEED
sp.p: And that letter hath she delivered, and there an end.

sp.speaker: VALENTINE
sp.p: I would it were no worse.

sp.speaker: SPEED
sp.p:
I'll warrant you, 'tis as well:
For often have you writ to her, and she, in modesty,
Or else for want of idle time, could not again reply;
Or fearing else some messenger that might her mind discover,
Herself hath taught her love himself to write unto her lover.
All this I speak in print, for in print I found it.
Why muse you, sir? 'tis dinner-time.

sp.speaker: VALENTINE
sp.p: I have dined.

sp.speaker: SPEED
sp.p:
Ay, but hearken, sir; though the chameleon Love can
feed on the air, I am one that am nourished by my
victuals, and would fain have meat. O, be not like
your mistress; be moved, be moved.

sp.speaker: PROTEUS
sp.p: Have patience, gentle Julia.

sp.speaker: JULIA
sp.p: I must, where is no remedy.

sp.speaker: PROTEUS
sp.p: When possibly I can, I will return.

sp.speaker: JULIA
sp.p:
If you turn not, you will return the sooner.
Keep this remembrance for thy Julia's sake.

sp.speaker: PROTEUS
sp.p: Why then, we'll make exchange; here, take you this.

sp.speaker: JULIA
sp.p: And seal the bargain with a holy kiss.

sp.speaker: PROTEUS
PANTHINO
sp.p: Sir Proteus, you are stay'd for.

sp.speaker: PROTEUS
sp.p:
Go; I come, I come.
Alas! this parting strikes poor lovers dumb.

sp.speaker: LAUNCE
sp.p:
Nay, 'twill be this hour ere I have done weeping;
all the kind of the Launces have this very fault. I
have received my proportion, like the prodigious
son, and am going with Sir Proteus to the Imperial's
court. I think Crab, my dog, be the sourest-natured
dog that lives: my mother weeping, my father
wailing, my sister crying, our maid howling, our cat
wringing her hands, and all our house in a great
perplexity, yet did not this cruel-hearted cur shed
one tear: he is a stone, a very pebble stone, and
has no more pity in him than a dog: a Jew would have
wept to have seen our parting; why, my grandam,
having no eyes, look you, wept herself blind at my
parting. Nay, I'll show you the manner of it. This
shoe is my father: no, this left shoe is my father:
no, no, this left shoe is my mother: nay, that
cannot be so neither: yes, it is so, it is so, it
hath the worser sole. This shoe, with the hole in
it, is my mother, and this my father; a vengeance
on't! there 'tis: now, sit, this staff is my
sister, for, look you, she is as white as a lily and
as small as a wand: this hat is Nan, our maid: I
am the dog: no, the dog is himself, and I am the
dog—Oh! the dog is me, and I am myself; ay, so,
so. Now come I to my father; Father, your blessing:
now should not the shoe speak a word for weeping:
now should I kiss my father; well, he weeps on. Now
come I to my mother: O, that she could speak now
like a wood woman! Well, I kiss her; why, there
'tis; here's my mother's breath up and down. Now
come I to my sister; mark the moan she makes. Now
the dog all this while sheds not a tear nor speaks a
word; but see how I lay the dust with my tears.

sp.speaker: PANTHINO
sp.p:
Launce, away, away, aboard! thy master is shipped
and thou art to post after with oars. What's the
matter? why weepest thou, man? Away, ass! You'll
lose the tide, if you tarry any longer.

sp.speaker: LAUNCE
sp.p:
It is no matter if the tied were lost; for it is the
unkindest tied that ever any man tied.

sp.speaker: PANTHINO
sp.p: What's the unkindest tide?

sp.speaker: LAUNCE
sp.p: Why, he that's tied here, Crab, my dog.

sp.speaker: PANTHINO
sp.p:
Tut, man, I mean thou'lt lose the flood, and, in
losing the flood, lose thy voyage, and, in losing
thy voyage, lose thy master, and, in losing thy
master, lose thy service, and, in losing thy
service,—Why dost thou stop my mouth?

sp.speaker: LAUNCE
sp.p: For fear thou shouldst lose thy tongue.

sp.speaker: PANTHINO
sp.p: Where should I lose my tongue?

sp.speaker: LAUNCE
sp.p: In thy tale.

sp.speaker: PANTHINO
sp.p: In thy tail!

sp.speaker: LAUNCE
sp.p:
Lose the tide, and the voyage, and the master, and
the service, and the tied! Why, man, if the river
were dry, I am able to fill it with my tears; if the
wind were down, I could drive the boat with my sighs.

sp.speaker: PANTHINO
sp.p: Come, come away, man; I was sent to call thee.

sp.speaker: LAUNCE
sp.p: Sir, call me what thou darest.

sp.speaker: PANTHINO
sp.p: Wilt thou go?

sp.speaker: LAUNCE
sp.p: Well, I will go.

p.stage: Enter SILVIA, VALENTINE, THURIO, and SPEED

sp.speaker: SILVIA
sp.p: Servant!

sp.speaker: VALENTINE
sp.p: Mistress?

sp.speaker: SPEED
sp.p: Master, Sir Thurio frowns on you.

sp.speaker: VALENTINE
sp.p: Ay, boy, it's for love.

sp.speaker: SPEED
sp.p: Not of you.

sp.speaker: VALENTINE
sp.p: Of my mistress, then.

sp.speaker: SPEED
sp.p: 'Twere good you knocked him.

sp.speaker: SILVIA
sp.p: Servant, you are sad.

sp.speaker: VALENTINE
sp.p: Indeed, madam, I seem so.

sp.speaker: THURIO
sp.p: Seem you that you are not?

sp.speaker: VALENTINE
sp.p: Haply I do.

sp.speaker: THURIO
sp.p: So do counterfeits.

sp.speaker: VALENTINE
sp.p: So do you.

sp.speaker: THURIO
sp.p: What seem I that I am not?

sp.speaker: VALENTINE
sp.p: Wise.

sp.speaker: THURIO
sp.p: What instance of the contrary?

sp.speaker: VALENTINE
sp.p: Your folly.

sp.speaker: THURIO
sp.p: And how quote you my folly?

sp.speaker: VALENTINE
sp.p: I quote it in your jerkin.

sp.speaker: THURIO
sp.p: My jerkin is a doublet.

sp.speaker: VALENTINE
sp.p: Well, then, I'll double your folly.

sp.speaker: THURIO
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: SILVIA
sp.p: What, angry, Sir Thurio! do you change colour?

sp.speaker: VALENTINE
sp.p: Give him leave, madam; he is a kind of chameleon.

sp.speaker: THURIO
sp.p:
That hath more mind to feed on your blood than live
in your air.

sp.speaker: VALENTINE
sp.p: You have said, sir.

sp.speaker: THURIO
sp.p: Ay, sir, and done too, for this time.

sp.speaker: VALENTINE
sp.p: I know it well, sir; you always end ere you begin.

sp.speaker: SILVIA
sp.p: A fine volley of words, gentlemen, and quickly shot off.

sp.speaker: VALENTINE
sp.p: 'Tis indeed, madam; we thank the giver.

sp.speaker: SILVIA
sp.p: Who is that, servant?

sp.speaker: VALENTINE
sp.p:
Yourself, sweet lady; for you gave the fire. Sir
Thurio borrows his wit from your ladyship's looks,
and spends what he borrows kindly in your company.

sp.speaker: THURIO
sp.p:
Sir, if you spend word for word with me, I shall
make your wit bankrupt.

sp.speaker: VALENTINE
sp.p:
I know it well, sir; you have an exchequer of words,
and, I think, no other treasure to give your
followers, for it appears by their bare liveries,
that they live by your bare words.

sp.speaker: SILVIA
sp.p: No more, gentlemen, no more:—here comes my father.

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.p:
Now, daughter Silvia, you are hard beset.
Sir Valentine, your father's in good health:
What say you to a letter from your friends
Of much good news?

sp.speaker: VALENTINE
sp.p:
My lord, I will be thankful.
To any happy messenger from thence.

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.p: Know ye Don Antonio, your countryman?

sp.speaker: VALENTINE
sp.p:
Ay, my good lord, I know the gentleman
To be of worth and worthy estimation
And not without desert so well reputed.

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.p: Hath he not a son?

sp.speaker: VALENTINE
sp.p:
Ay, my good lord; a son that well deserves
The honour and regard of such a father.

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.p: You know him well?

sp.speaker: VALENTINE
sp.p:
I know him as myself; for from our infancy
We have conversed and spent our hours together:
And though myself have been an idle truant,
Omitting the sweet benefit of time
To clothe mine age with angel-like perfection,
Yet hath Sir Proteus, for that's his name,
Made use and fair advantage of his days;
His years but young, but his experience old;
His head unmellow'd, but his judgment ripe;
And, in a word, for far behind his worth
Comes all the praises that I now bestow,
He is complete in feature and in mind
With all good grace to grace a gentleman.

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.p:
Beshrew me, sir, but if he make this good,
He is as worthy for an empress' love
As meet to be an emperor's counsellor.
Well, sir, this gentleman is come to me,
With commendation from great potentates;
And here he means to spend his time awhile:
I think 'tis no unwelcome news to you.

sp.speaker: VALENTINE
sp.p: Should I have wish'd a thing, it had been he.

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.p:
Welcome him then according to his worth.
Silvia, I speak to you, and you, Sir Thurio;
For Valentine, I need not cite him to it:
I will send him hither to you presently.

sp.speaker: VALENTINE
sp.p:
This is the gentleman I told your ladyship
Had come along with me, but that his mistress
Did hold his eyes lock'd in her crystal looks.

sp.speaker: SILVIA
sp.p:
Belike that now she hath enfranchised them
Upon some other pawn for fealty.

sp.speaker: VALENTINE
sp.p: Nay, sure, I think she holds them prisoners still.

sp.speaker: SILVIA
sp.p:
Nay, then he should be blind; and, being blind
How could he see his way to seek out you?

sp.speaker: VALENTINE
sp.p: Why, lady, Love hath twenty pair of eyes.

sp.speaker: THURIO
sp.p: They say that Love hath not an eye at all.

sp.speaker: VALENTINE
sp.p:
To see such lovers, Thurio, as yourself:
Upon a homely object Love can wink.

sp.speaker: SILVIA
sp.p: Have done, have done; here comes the gentleman.

sp.speaker: VALENTINE
sp.p:
Welcome, dear Proteus! Mistress, I beseech you,
Confirm his welcome with some special favour.

sp.speaker: SILVIA
sp.p:
His worth is warrant for his welcome hither,
If this be he you oft have wish'd to hear from.

sp.speaker: VALENTINE
sp.p:
Mistress, it is: sweet lady, entertain him
To be my fellow-servant to your ladyship.

sp.speaker: SILVIA
sp.p: Too low a mistress for so high a servant.

sp.speaker: PROTEUS
sp.p:
Not so, sweet lady: but too mean a servant
To have a look of such a worthy mistress.

sp.speaker: VALENTINE
sp.p:
Leave off discourse of disability:
Sweet lady, entertain him for your servant.

sp.speaker: PROTEUS
sp.p: My duty will I boast of; nothing else.

sp.speaker: SILVIA
sp.p:
And duty never yet did want his meed:
Servant, you are welcome to a worthless mistress.

sp.speaker: PROTEUS
sp.p: I'll die on him that says so but yourself.

sp.speaker: SILVIA
sp.p: That you are welcome?

sp.speaker: PROTEUS
sp.p: That you are worthless.

sp.speaker: THURIO
sp.p: Madam, my lord your father would speak with you.

sp.speaker: SILVIA
sp.p:
I wait upon his pleasure. Come, Sir Thurio,
Go with me. Once more, new servant, welcome:
I'll leave you to confer of home affairs;
When you have done, we look to hear from you.

sp.speaker: PROTEUS
sp.p: We'll both attend upon your ladyship.

sp.speaker: VALENTINE
sp.p: Now, tell me, how do all from whence you came?

sp.speaker: PROTEUS
sp.p: Your friends are well and have them much commended.

sp.speaker: VALENTINE
sp.p: And how do yours?

sp.speaker: PROTEUS
sp.p: I left them all in health.

sp.speaker: VALENTINE
sp.p: How does your lady? and how thrives your love?

sp.speaker: PROTEUS
sp.p:
My tales of love were wont to weary you;
I know you joy not in a love discourse.

sp.speaker: VALENTINE
sp.p:
Ay, Proteus, but that life is alter'd now:
I have done penance for contemning Love,
Whose high imperious thoughts have punish'd me
With bitter fasts, with penitential groans,
With nightly tears and daily heart-sore sighs;
For in revenge of my contempt of love,
Love hath chased sleep from my enthralled eyes
And made them watchers of mine own heart's sorrow.
O gentle Proteus, Love's a mighty lord,
And hath so humbled me, as, I confess,
There is no woe to his correction,
Nor to his service no such joy on earth.
Now no discourse, except it be of love;
Now can I break my fast, dine, sup and sleep,
Upon the very naked name of love.

sp.speaker: PROTEUS
sp.p:
Enough; I read your fortune in your eye.
Was this the idol that you worship so?

sp.speaker: VALENTINE
sp.p: Even she; and is she not a heavenly saint?

sp.speaker: PROTEUS
sp.p: No; but she is an earthly paragon.

sp.speaker: VALENTINE
sp.p: Call her divine.

sp.speaker: PROTEUS
sp.p: I will not flatter her.

sp.speaker: VALENTINE
sp.p: O, flatter me; for love delights in praises.

sp.speaker: PROTEUS
sp.p:
When I was sick, you gave me bitter pills,
And I must minister the like to you.

sp.speaker: VALENTINE
sp.p:
Then speak the truth by her; if not divine,
Yet let her be a principality,
Sovereign to all the creatures on the earth.

sp.speaker: PROTEUS
sp.p: Except my mistress.

sp.speaker: VALENTINE
sp.p:
Sweet, except not any;
Except thou wilt except against my love.

sp.speaker: PROTEUS
sp.p: Have I not reason to prefer mine own?

sp.speaker: VALENTINE
sp.p:
And I will help thee to prefer her too:
She shall be dignified with this high honour—
To bear my lady's train, lest the base earth
Should from her vesture chance to steal a kiss
And, of so great a favour growing proud,
Disdain to root the summer-swelling flower
And make rough winter everlastingly.

sp.speaker: PROTEUS
sp.p: Why, Valentine, what braggardism is this?

sp.speaker: VALENTINE
PROTEUS
sp.p: Then let her alone.

sp.speaker: VALENTINE
sp.p:
Not for the world: why, man, she is mine own,
And I as rich in having such a jewel
As twenty seas, if all their sand were pearl,
The water nectar and the rocks pure gold.
Forgive me that I do not dream on thee,
Because thou see'st me dote upon my love.
My foolish rival, that her father likes
Only for his possessions are so huge,
Is gone with her along, and I must after,
For love, thou know'st, is full of jealousy.

sp.speaker: PROTEUS
sp.p: But she loves you?

sp.speaker: VALENTINE
sp.p:
Ay, and we are betroth'd: nay, more, our,
marriage-hour,
With all the cunning manner of our flight,
Determined of; how I must climb her window,
The ladder made of cords, and all the means
Plotted and 'greed on for my happiness.
Good Proteus, go with me to my chamber,
In these affairs to aid me with thy counsel.

sp.speaker: PROTEUS
sp.p:
Go on before; I shall inquire you forth:
I must unto the road, to disembark
Some necessaries that I needs must use,
And then I'll presently attend you.

sp.speaker: VALENTINE
sp.p: Will you make haste?

sp.speaker: PROTEUS
sp.p: I will.

Even as one heat another heat expels,
Or as one nail by strength drives out another,
So the remembrance of my former love
Is by a newer object quite forgotten.
Is it mine, or Valentine's praise,
Her true perfection, or my false transgression,
That makes me reasonless to reason thus?
She is fair; and so is Julia that I love—
That I did love, for now my love is thaw'd;
Which, like a waxen image, 'gainst a fire,
Bears no impression of the thing it was.
Methinks my zeal to Valentine is cold,
And that I love him not as I was wont.
O, but I love his lady too too much,
And that's the reason I love him so little.
How shall I dote on her with more advice,
That thus without advice begin to love her!
'Tis but her picture I have yet beheld,
And that hath dazzled my reason's light;
But when I look on her perfections,
There is no reason but I shall be blind.
If I can cheque my erring love, I will;
If not, to compass her I'll use my skill.

sp.speaker: SPEED
sp.p: Launce! by mine honesty, welcome to Milan!

sp.speaker: LAUNCE
sp.p:
Forswear not thyself, sweet youth, for I am not
welcome. I reckon this always, that a man is never
undone till he be hanged, nor never welcome to a
place till some certain shot be paid and the hostess
say 'Welcome!'

sp.speaker: SPEED
sp.p:
Come on, you madcap, I'll to the alehouse with you
presently; where, for one shot of five pence, thou
shalt have five thousand welcomes. But, sirrah, how
did thy master part with Madam Julia?

sp.speaker: LAUNCE
sp.p:
Marry, after they closed in earnest, they parted very
fairly in jest.

sp.speaker: SPEED
sp.p: But shall she marry him?

sp.speaker: LAUNCE
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: SPEED
sp.p: How then? shall he marry her?

sp.speaker: LAUNCE
sp.p: No, neither.

sp.speaker: SPEED
sp.p: What, are they broken?

sp.speaker: LAUNCE
sp.p: No, they are both as whole as a fish.

sp.speaker: SPEED
sp.p: Why, then, how stands the matter with them?

sp.speaker: LAUNCE
sp.p:
Marry, thus: when it stands well with him, it
stands well with her.

sp.speaker: SPEED
sp.p: What an ass art thou! I understand thee not.

sp.speaker: LAUNCE
sp.p:
What a block art thou, that thou canst not! My
staff understands me.

sp.speaker: SPEED
sp.p: What thou sayest?

sp.speaker: LAUNCE
sp.p:
Ay, and what I do too: look thee, I'll but lean,
and my staff understands me.

sp.speaker: SPEED
sp.p: It stands under thee, indeed.

sp.speaker: LAUNCE
sp.p: Why, stand-under and under-stand is all one.

sp.speaker: SPEED
sp.p: But tell me true, will't be a match?

sp.speaker: LAUNCE
sp.p:
Ask my dog: if he say ay, it will! if he say no,
it will; if he shake his tail and say nothing, it will.

sp.speaker: SPEED
sp.p: The conclusion is then that it will.

sp.speaker: LAUNCE
sp.p: Thou shalt never get such a secret from me but by a parable.

sp.speaker: SPEED
sp.p:
'Tis well that I get it so. But, Launce, how sayest
thou, that my master is become a notable lover?

sp.speaker: LAUNCE
sp.p: I never knew him otherwise.

sp.speaker: SPEED
sp.p: Than how?

sp.speaker: LAUNCE
sp.p: A notable lubber, as thou reportest him to be.

sp.speaker: SPEED
sp.p: Why, thou whoreson ass, thou mistakest me.

sp.speaker: LAUNCE
sp.p: Why, fool, I meant not thee; I meant thy master.

sp.speaker: SPEED
sp.p: I tell thee, my master is become a hot lover.

sp.speaker: LAUNCE
sp.p:
Why, I tell thee, I care not though he burn himself
in love. If thou wilt, go with me to the alehouse;
if not, thou art an Hebrew, a Jew, and not worth the
name of a Christian.

sp.speaker: SPEED
sp.p: Why?

sp.speaker: LAUNCE
sp.p:
Because thou hast not so much charity in thee as to
go to the ale with a Christian. Wilt thou go?

sp.speaker: SPEED
sp.p: At thy service.

sp.speaker: PROTEUS
sp.p:
To leave my Julia, shall I be forsworn;
To love fair Silvia, shall I be forsworn;
To wrong my friend, I shall be much forsworn;
And even that power which gave me first my oath
Provokes me to this threefold perjury;
Love bade me swear and Love bids me forswear.
O sweet-suggesting Love, if thou hast sinned,
Teach me, thy tempted subject, to excuse it!
At first I did adore a twinkling star,
But now I worship a celestial sun.
Unheedful vows may heedfully be broken,
And he wants wit that wants resolved will
To learn his wit to exchange the bad for better.
Fie, fie, unreverend tongue! to call her bad,
Whose sovereignty so oft thou hast preferr'd
With twenty thousand soul-confirming oaths.
I cannot leave to love, and yet I do;
But there I leave to love where I should love.
Julia I lose and Valentine I lose:
If I keep them, I needs must lose myself;
If I lose them, thus find I by their loss
For Valentine myself, for Julia Silvia.
I to myself am dearer than a friend,
For love is still most precious in itself;
And Silvia—witness Heaven, that made her fair!—
Shows Julia but a swarthy Ethiope.
I will forget that Julia is alive,
Remembering that my love to her is dead;
And Valentine I'll hold an enemy,
Aiming at Silvia as a sweeter friend.
I cannot now prove constant to myself,
Without some treachery used to Valentine.
This night he meaneth with a corded ladder
To climb celestial Silvia's chamber-window,
Myself in counsel, his competitor.
Now presently I'll give her father notice
Of their disguising and pretended flight;
Who, all enraged, will banish Valentine;
For Thurio, he intends, shall wed his daughter;
But, Valentine being gone, I'll quickly cross
By some sly trick blunt Thurio's dull proceeding.
Love, lend me wings to make my purpose swift,
As thou hast lent me wit to plot this drift!

sp.speaker: JULIA
sp.p:
Counsel, Lucetta; gentle girl, assist me;
And even in kind love I do conjure thee,
Who art the table wherein all my thoughts
Are visibly character'd and engraved,
To lesson me and tell me some good mean
How, with my honour, I may undertake
A journey to my loving Proteus.

sp.speaker: LUCETTA
sp.p: Alas, the way is wearisome and long!

sp.speaker: JULIA
sp.p:
A true-devoted pilgrim is not weary
To measure kingdoms with his feeble steps;
Much less shall she that hath Love's wings to fly,
And when the flight is made to one so dear,
Of such divine perfection, as Sir Proteus.

sp.speaker: LUCETTA
sp.p: Better forbear till Proteus make return.

sp.speaker: JULIA
sp.p:
O, know'st thou not his looks are my soul's food?
Pity the dearth that I have pined in,
By longing for that food so long a time.
Didst thou but know the inly touch of love,
Thou wouldst as soon go kindle fire with snow
As seek to quench the fire of love with words.

sp.speaker: LUCETTA
sp.p:
I do not seek to quench your love's hot fire,
But qualify the fire's extreme rage,
Lest it should burn above the bounds of reason.

sp.speaker: JULIA
sp.p:
The more thou damm'st it up, the more it burns.
The current that with gentle murmur glides,
Thou know'st, being stopp'd, impatiently doth rage;
But when his fair course is not hindered,
He makes sweet music with the enamell'ed stones,
Giving a gentle kiss to every sedge
He overtaketh in his pilgrimage,
And so by many winding nooks he strays
With willing sport to the wild ocean.
Then let me go and hinder not my course
I'll be as patient as a gentle stream
And make a pastime of each weary step,
Till the last step have brought me to my love;
And there I'll rest, as after much turmoil
A blessed soul doth in Elysium.

sp.speaker: LUCETTA
sp.p: But in what habit will you go along?

sp.speaker: JULIA
sp.p:
Not like a woman; for I would prevent
The loose encounters of lascivious men:
Gentle Lucetta, fit me with such weeds
As may beseem some well-reputed page.

sp.speaker: LUCETTA
sp.p: Why, then, your ladyship must cut your hair.

sp.speaker: JULIA
sp.p:
No, girl, I'll knit it up in silken strings
With twenty odd-conceited true-love knots.
To be fantastic may become a youth
Of greater time than I shall show to be.

sp.speaker: LUCETTA
sp.p: What fashion, madam shall I make your breeches?

sp.speaker: JULIA
sp.p:
That fits as well as 'Tell me, good my lord,
What compass will you wear your farthingale?'
Why even what fashion thou best likest, Lucetta.

sp.speaker: LUCETTA
sp.p: You must needs have them with a codpiece, madam.

sp.speaker: JULIA
sp.p: Out, out, Lucetta! that would be ill-favour'd.

sp.speaker: LUCETTA
sp.p:
A round hose, madam, now's not worth a pin,
Unless you have a codpiece to stick pins on.

sp.speaker: JULIA
sp.p:
Lucetta, as thou lovest me, let me have
What thou thinkest meet and is most mannerly.
But tell me, wench, how will the world repute me
For undertaking so unstaid a journey?
I fear me, it will make me scandalized.

sp.speaker: LUCETTA
sp.p: If you think so, then stay at home and go not.

sp.speaker: JULIA
sp.p: Nay, that I will not.

sp.speaker: LUCETTA
sp.p:
Then never dream on infamy, but go.
If Proteus like your journey when you come,
No matter who's displeased when you are gone:
I fear me, he will scarce be pleased withal.

sp.speaker: JULIA
sp.p:
That is the least, Lucetta, of my fear:
A thousand oaths, an ocean of his tears
And instances of infinite of love
Warrant me welcome to my Proteus.

sp.speaker: LUCETTA
sp.p: All these are servants to deceitful men.

sp.speaker: JULIA
sp.p:
Base men, that use them to so base effect!
But truer stars did govern Proteus' birth
His words are bonds, his oaths are oracles,
His love sincere, his thoughts immaculate,
His tears pure messengers sent from his heart,
His heart as far from fraud as heaven from earth.

sp.speaker: LUCETTA
sp.p: Pray heaven he prove so, when you come to him!

sp.speaker: JULIA
sp.p:
Now, as thou lovest me, do him not that wrong
To bear a hard opinion of his truth:
Only deserve my love by loving him;
And presently go with me to my chamber,
To take a note of what I stand in need of,
To furnish me upon my longing journey.
All that is mine I leave at thy dispose,
My goods, my lands, my reputation;
Only, in lieu thereof, dispatch me hence.
Come, answer not, but to it presently!
I am impatient of my tarriance.

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.p:
Sir Thurio, give us leave, I pray, awhile;
We have some secrets to confer about.
Now, tell me, Proteus, what's your will with me?

sp.speaker: PROTEUS
sp.p:
My gracious lord, that which I would discover
The law of friendship bids me to conceal;
But when I call to mind your gracious favours
Done to me, undeserving as I am,
My duty pricks me on to utter that
Which else no worldly good should draw from me.
Know, worthy prince, Sir Valentine, my friend,
This night intends to steal away your daughter:
Myself am one made privy to the plot.
I know you have determined to bestow her
On Thurio, whom your gentle daughter hates;
And should she thus be stol'n away from you,
It would be much vexation to your age.
Thus, for my duty's sake, I rather chose
To cross my friend in his intended drift
Than, by concealing it, heap on your head
A pack of sorrows which would press you down,
Being unprevented, to your timeless grave.

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.p:
Proteus, I thank thee for thine honest care;
Which to requite, command me while I live.
This love of theirs myself have often seen,
Haply when they have judged me fast asleep,
And oftentimes have purposed to forbid
Sir Valentine her company and my court:
But fearing lest my jealous aim might err
And so unworthily disgrace the man,
A rashness that I ever yet have shunn'd,
I gave him gentle looks, thereby to find
That which thyself hast now disclosed to me.
And, that thou mayst perceive my fear of this,
Knowing that tender youth is soon suggested,
I nightly lodge her in an upper tower,
The key whereof myself have ever kept;
And thence she cannot be convey'd away.

sp.speaker: PROTEUS
DUKE
sp.p:
Upon mine honour, he shall never know
That I had any light from thee of this.

sp.speaker: PROTEUS
sp.p: Adieu, my Lord; Sir Valentine is coming.

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.p: Sir Valentine, whither away so fast?

sp.speaker: VALENTINE
sp.p:
Please it your grace, there is a messenger
That stays to bear my letters to my friends,
And I am going to deliver them.

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.p: Be they of much import?

sp.speaker: VALENTINE
sp.p:
The tenor of them doth but signify
My health and happy being at your court.

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.p:
Nay then, no matter; stay with me awhile;
I am to break with thee of some affairs
That touch me near, wherein thou must be secret.
'Tis not unknown to thee that I have sought
To match my friend Sir Thurio to my daughter.

sp.speaker: VALENTINE
sp.p:
I know it well, my Lord; and, sure, the match
Were rich and honourable; besides, the gentleman
Is full of virtue, bounty, worth and qualities
Beseeming such a wife as your fair daughter:
Cannot your Grace win her to fancy him?

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.p:
No, trust me; she is peevish, sullen, froward,
Proud, disobedient, stubborn, lacking duty,
Neither regarding that she is my child
Nor fearing me as if I were her father;
And, may I say to thee, this pride of hers,
Upon advice, hath drawn my love from her;
And, where I thought the remnant of mine age
Should have been cherish'd by her child-like duty,
I now am full resolved to take a wife
And turn her out to who will take her in:
Then let her beauty be her wedding-dower;
For me and my possessions she esteems not.

sp.speaker: VALENTINE
sp.p: What would your Grace have me to do in this?

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.p:
There is a lady in Verona here
Whom I affect; but she is nice and coy
And nought esteems my aged eloquence:
Now therefore would I have thee to my tutor—
For long agone I have forgot to court;
Besides, the fashion of the time is changed—
How and which way I may bestow myself
To be regarded in her sun-bright eye.

sp.speaker: VALENTINE
sp.p:
Win her with gifts, if she respect not words:
Dumb jewels often in their silent kind
More than quick words do move a woman's mind.

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.p: But she did scorn a present that I sent her.

sp.speaker: VALENTINE
DUKE
sp.p:
But she I mean is promised by her friends
Unto a youthful gentleman of worth,
And kept severely from resort of men,
That no man hath access by day to her.

sp.speaker: VALENTINE
sp.p: Why, then, I would resort to her by night.

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.p:
Ay, but the doors be lock'd and keys kept safe,
That no man hath recourse to her by night.

sp.speaker: VALENTINE
sp.p: What lets but one may enter at her window?

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.p:
Her chamber is aloft, far from the ground,
And built so shelving that one cannot climb it
Without apparent hazard of his life.

sp.speaker: VALENTINE
sp.p:
Why then, a ladder quaintly made of cords,
To cast up, with a pair of anchoring hooks,
Would serve to scale another Hero's tower,
So bold Leander would adventure it.

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.p:
Now, as thou art a gentleman of blood,
Advise me where I may have such a ladder.

sp.speaker: VALENTINE
sp.p: When would you use it? pray, sir, tell me that.

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.p:
This very night; for Love is like a child,
That longs for every thing that he can come by.

sp.speaker: VALENTINE
sp.p: By seven o'clock I'll get you such a ladder.

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.p:
But, hark thee; I will go to her alone:
How shall I best convey the ladder thither?

sp.speaker: VALENTINE
sp.p:
It will be light, my lord, that you may bear it
Under a cloak that is of any length.

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.p: A cloak as long as thine will serve the turn?

sp.speaker: VALENTINE
sp.p: Ay, my good lord.

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.p:
Then let me see thy cloak:
I'll get me one of such another length.

sp.speaker: VALENTINE
sp.p: Why, any cloak will serve the turn, my lord.

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.p:
How shall I fashion me to wear a cloak?
I pray thee, let me feel thy cloak upon me.
What letter is this same? What's here? 'To Silvia'!
And here an engine fit for my proceeding.
I'll be so bold to break the seal for once.

'My thoughts do harbour with my Silvia nightly,
And slaves they are to me that send them flying:
O, could their master come and go as lightly,
Himself would lodge where senseless they are lying!
My herald thoughts in thy pure bosom rest them:
While I, their king, that hither them importune,
Do curse the grace that with such grace hath bless'd them,
Because myself do want my servants' fortune:
I curse myself, for they are sent by me,
That they should harbour where their lord would be.'
What's here?
'Silvia, this night I will enfranchise thee.'
'Tis so; and here's the ladder for the purpose.
Why, Phaeton,—for thou art Merops' son,—
Wilt thou aspire to guide the heavenly car
And with thy daring folly burn the world?
Wilt thou reach stars, because they shine on thee?
Go, base intruder! overweening slave!
Bestow thy fawning smiles on equal mates,
And think my patience, more than thy desert,
Is privilege for thy departure hence:
Thank me for this more than for all the favours
Which all too much I have bestow'd on thee.
But if thou linger in my territories
Longer than swiftest expedition
Will give thee time to leave our royal court,
By heaven! my wrath shall far exceed the love
I ever bore my daughter or thyself.
Be gone! I will not hear thy vain excuse;
But, as thou lovest thy life, make speed from hence.

sp.speaker: VALENTINE
sp.p:
And why not death rather than living torment?
To die is to be banish'd from myself;
And Silvia is myself: banish'd from her
Is self from self: a deadly banishment!
What light is light, if Silvia be not seen?
What joy is joy, if Silvia be not by?
Unless it be to think that she is by
And feed upon the shadow of perfection
Except I be by Silvia in the night,
There is no music in the nightingale;
Unless I look on Silvia in the day,
There is no day for me to look upon;
She is my essence, and I leave to be,
If I be not by her fair influence
Foster'd, illumined, cherish'd, kept alive.
I fly not death, to fly his deadly doom:
Tarry I here, I but attend on death:
But, fly I hence, I fly away from life.

sp.speaker: PROTEUS
sp.p: Run, boy, run, run, and seek him out.

sp.speaker: LAUNCE
sp.p: Soho, soho!

sp.speaker: PROTEUS
sp.p: What seest thou?

sp.speaker: LAUNCE
sp.p:
Him we go to find: there's not a hair on's head
but 'tis a Valentine.

sp.speaker: PROTEUS
sp.p: Valentine?

sp.speaker: VALENTINE
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: PROTEUS
sp.p: Who then? his spirit?

sp.speaker: VALENTINE
sp.p: Neither.

sp.speaker: PROTEUS
sp.p: What then?

sp.speaker: VALENTINE
sp.p: Nothing.

sp.speaker: LAUNCE
sp.p: Can nothing speak? Master, shall I strike?

sp.speaker: PROTEUS
sp.p: Who wouldst thou strike?

sp.speaker: LAUNCE
sp.p: Nothing.

sp.speaker: PROTEUS
sp.p: Villain, forbear.

sp.speaker: LAUNCE
sp.p: Why, sir, I'll strike nothing: I pray you,—

sp.speaker: PROTEUS
sp.p: Sirrah, I say, forbear. Friend Valentine, a word.

sp.speaker: VALENTINE
sp.p:
My ears are stopt and cannot hear good news,
So much of bad already hath possess'd them.

sp.speaker: PROTEUS
sp.p:
Then in dumb silence will I bury mine,
For they are harsh, untuneable and bad.

sp.speaker: VALENTINE
sp.p: Is Silvia dead?

sp.speaker: PROTEUS
sp.p: No, Valentine.

sp.speaker: VALENTINE
sp.p:
No Valentine, indeed, for sacred Silvia.
Hath she forsworn me?

sp.speaker: PROTEUS
sp.p: No, Valentine.

sp.speaker: VALENTINE
sp.p:
No Valentine, if Silvia have forsworn me.
What is your news?

sp.speaker: LAUNCE
sp.p: Sir, there is a proclamation that you are vanished.

sp.speaker: PROTEUS
sp.p:
That thou art banished—O, that's the news!—
From hence, from Silvia and from me thy friend.

sp.speaker: VALENTINE
sp.p:
O, I have fed upon this woe already,
And now excess of it will make me surfeit.
Doth Silvia know that I am banished?

sp.speaker: PROTEUS
sp.p:
Ay, ay; and she hath offer'd to the doom—
Which, unreversed, stands in effectual force—
A sea of melting pearl, which some call tears:
Those at her father's churlish feet she tender'd;
With them, upon her knees, her humble self;
Wringing her hands, whose whiteness so became them
As if but now they waxed pale for woe:
But neither bended knees, pure hands held up,
Sad sighs, deep groans, nor silver-shedding tears,
Could penetrate her uncompassionate sire;
But Valentine, if he be ta'en, must die.
Besides, her intercession chafed him so,
When she for thy repeal was suppliant,
That to close prison he commanded her,
With many bitter threats of biding there.

sp.speaker: VALENTINE
sp.p:
No more; unless the next word that thou speak'st
Have some malignant power upon my life:
If so, I pray thee, breathe it in mine ear,
As ending anthem of my endless dolour.

sp.speaker: PROTEUS
sp.p:
Cease to lament for that thou canst not help,
And study help for that which thou lament'st.
Time is the nurse and breeder of all good.
Here if thou stay, thou canst not see thy love;
Besides, thy staying will abridge thy life.
Hope is a lover's staff; walk hence with that
And manage it against despairing thoughts.
Thy letters may be here, though thou art hence;
Which, being writ to me, shall be deliver'd
Even in the milk-white bosom of thy love.
The time now serves not to expostulate:
Come, I'll convey thee through the city-gate;
And, ere I part with thee, confer at large
Of all that may concern thy love-affairs.
As thou lovest Silvia, though not for thyself,
Regard thy danger, and along with me!

sp.speaker: VALENTINE
sp.p:
I pray thee, Launce, an if thou seest my boy,
Bid him make haste and meet me at the North-gate.

sp.speaker: PROTEUS
sp.p: Go, sirrah, find him out. Come, Valentine.

sp.speaker: VALENTINE
sp.p: O my dear Silvia! Hapless Valentine!

sp.speaker: LAUNCE
sp.p:
I am but a fool, look you; and yet I have the wit to
think my master is a kind of a knave: but that's
all one, if he be but one knave. He lives not now
that knows me to be in love; yet I am in love; but a
team of horse shall not pluck that from me; nor who
'tis I love; and yet 'tis a woman; but what woman, I
will not tell myself; and yet 'tis a milkmaid; yet
'tis not a maid, for she hath had gossips; yet 'tis
a maid, for she is her master's maid, and serves for
wages. She hath more qualities than a water-spaniel;
which is much in a bare Christian.

Here is the cate-log of her condition.
'Imprimis: She can fetch and carry.' Why, a horse
can do no more: nay, a horse cannot fetch, but only
carry; therefore is she better than a jade. 'Item:
She can milk;' look you, a sweet virtue in a maid
with clean hands.

sp.speaker: SPEED
sp.p:
How now, Signior Launce! what news with your
mastership?

sp.speaker: LAUNCE
sp.p: With my master's ship? why, it is at sea.

sp.speaker: SPEED
sp.p:
Well, your old vice still; mistake the word. What
news, then, in your paper?

sp.speaker: LAUNCE
sp.p: The blackest news that ever thou heardest.

sp.speaker: SPEED
sp.p: Why, man, how black?

sp.speaker: LAUNCE
sp.p: Why, as black as ink.

sp.speaker: SPEED
sp.p: Let me read them.

sp.speaker: LAUNCE
sp.p: Fie on thee, jolt-head! thou canst not read.

sp.speaker: SPEED
sp.p: Thou liest; I can.

sp.speaker: LAUNCE
sp.p: I will try thee. Tell me this: who begot thee?

sp.speaker: SPEED
sp.p: Marry, the son of my grandfather.

sp.speaker: LAUNCE
sp.p:
O illiterate loiterer! it was the son of thy
grandmother: this proves that thou canst not read.

sp.speaker: SPEED
sp.p: Come, fool, come; try me in thy paper.

sp.speaker: LAUNCE
sp.p: There; and St. Nicholas be thy speed!

sp.speaker: SPEED
sp.p: 'Imprimis: She can milk.'

sp.speaker: LAUNCE
sp.p: Ay, that she can.

sp.speaker: SPEED
sp.p: 'Item: She brews good ale.'

sp.speaker: LAUNCE
sp.p:
And thereof comes the proverb: 'Blessing of your
heart, you brew good ale.'

sp.speaker: SPEED
sp.p: 'Item: She can sew.'

sp.speaker: LAUNCE
sp.p: That's as much as to say, Can she so?

sp.speaker: SPEED
sp.p: 'Item: She can knit.'

sp.speaker: LAUNCE
sp.p:
What need a man care for a stock with a wench, when
she can knit him a stock?

sp.speaker: SPEED
sp.p: 'Item: She can wash and scour.'

sp.speaker: LAUNCE
sp.p:
A special virtue: for then she need not be washed
and scoured.

sp.speaker: SPEED
sp.p: 'Item: She can spin.'

sp.speaker: LAUNCE
sp.p:
Then may I set the world on wheels, when she can
spin for her living.

sp.speaker: SPEED
sp.p: 'Item: She hath many nameless virtues.'

sp.speaker: LAUNCE
sp.p:
That's as much as to say, bastard virtues; that,
indeed, know not their fathers and therefore have no names.

sp.speaker: SPEED
sp.p: 'Here follow her vices.'

sp.speaker: LAUNCE
sp.p: Close at the heels of her virtues.

sp.speaker: SPEED
sp.p:
'Item: She is not to be kissed fasting in respect
of her breath.'

sp.speaker: LAUNCE
sp.p: Well, that fault may be mended with a breakfast. Read on.

sp.speaker: SPEED
sp.p: 'Item: She hath a sweet mouth.'

sp.speaker: LAUNCE
sp.p: That makes amends for her sour breath.

sp.speaker: SPEED
sp.p: 'Item: She doth talk in her sleep.'

sp.speaker: LAUNCE
sp.p: It's no matter for that, so she sleep not in her talk.

sp.speaker: SPEED
sp.p: 'Item: She is slow in words.'

sp.speaker: LAUNCE
sp.p:
O villain, that set this down among her vices! To
be slow in words is a woman's only virtue: I pray
thee, out with't, and place it for her chief virtue.

sp.speaker: SPEED
sp.p: 'Item: She is proud.'

sp.speaker: LAUNCE
sp.p:
Out with that too; it was Eve's legacy, and cannot
be ta'en from her.

sp.speaker: SPEED
sp.p: 'Item: She hath no teeth.'

sp.speaker: LAUNCE
sp.p: I care not for that neither, because I love crusts.

sp.speaker: SPEED
sp.p: 'Item: She is curst.'

sp.speaker: LAUNCE
sp.p: Well, the best is, she hath no teeth to bite.

sp.speaker: SPEED
sp.p: 'Item: She will often praise her liquor.'

sp.speaker: LAUNCE
sp.p:
If her liquor be good, she shall: if she will not, I
will; for good things should be praised.

sp.speaker: SPEED
sp.p: 'Item: She is too liberal.'

sp.speaker: LAUNCE
sp.p:
Of her tongue she cannot, for that's writ down she
is slow of; of her purse she shall not, for that
I'll keep shut: now, of another thing she may, and
that cannot I help. Well, proceed.

sp.speaker: SPEED
sp.p:
'Item: She hath more hair than wit, and more faults
than hairs, and more wealth than faults.'

sp.speaker: LAUNCE
sp.p:
Stop there; I'll have her: she was mine, and not
mine, twice or thrice in that last article.
Rehearse that once more.

sp.speaker: SPEED
sp.p: 'Item: She hath more hair than wit,'—

sp.speaker: LAUNCE
sp.p:
More hair than wit? It may be; I'll prove it. The
cover of the salt hides the salt, and therefore it
is more than the salt; the hair that covers the wit
is more than the wit, for the greater hides the
less. What's next?

sp.speaker: SPEED
sp.p: 'And more faults than hairs,'—

sp.speaker: LAUNCE
sp.p: That's monstrous: O, that that were out!

sp.speaker: SPEED
sp.p: 'And more wealth than faults.'

sp.speaker: LAUNCE
sp.p:
Why, that word makes the faults gracious. Well,
I'll have her; and if it be a match, as nothing is
impossible,—

sp.speaker: SPEED
sp.p: What then?

sp.speaker: LAUNCE
sp.p:
Why, then will I tell thee—that thy master stays
for thee at the North-gate.

sp.speaker: SPEED
sp.p: For me?

sp.speaker: LAUNCE
sp.p:
For thee! ay, who art thou? he hath stayed for a
better man than thee.

sp.speaker: SPEED
sp.p: And must I go to him?

sp.speaker: LAUNCE
sp.p:
Thou must run to him, for thou hast stayed so long
that going will scarce serve the turn.

sp.speaker: SPEED
sp.p: Why didst not tell me sooner? pox of your love letters!

sp.speaker: LAUNCE
sp.p:
Now will he be swinged for reading my letter; an
unmannerly slave, that will thrust himself into
secrets! I'll after, to rejoice in the boy's correction.

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.p:
Sir Thurio, fear not but that she will love you,
Now Valentine is banish'd from her sight.

sp.speaker: THURIO
sp.p:
Since his exile she hath despised me most,
Forsworn my company and rail'd at me,
That I am desperate of obtaining her.

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.p:
This weak impress of love is as a figure
Trenched in ice, which with an hour's heat
Dissolves to water and doth lose his form.
A little time will melt her frozen thoughts
And worthless Valentine shall be forgot.

How now, Sir Proteus! Is your countryman
According to our proclamation gone?

sp.speaker: PROTEUS
sp.p: Gone, my good lord.

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.p: My daughter takes his going grievously.

sp.speaker: PROTEUS
sp.p: A little time, my lord, will kill that grief.

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.p:
So I believe; but Thurio thinks not so.
Proteus, the good conceit I hold of thee—
For thou hast shown some sign of good desert—
Makes me the better to confer with thee.

sp.speaker: PROTEUS
sp.p:
Longer than I prove loyal to your grace
Let me not live to look upon your grace.

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.p:
Thou know'st how willingly I would effect
The match between Sir Thurio and my daughter.

sp.speaker: PROTEUS
sp.p: I do, my lord.

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.p:
And also, I think, thou art not ignorant
How she opposes her against my will

sp.speaker: PROTEUS
sp.p: She did, my lord, when Valentine was here.

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.p:
Ay, and perversely she persevers so.
What might we do to make the girl forget
The love of Valentine and love Sir Thurio?

sp.speaker: PROTEUS
sp.p:
The best way is to slander Valentine
With falsehood, cowardice and poor descent,
Three things that women highly hold in hate.

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.p: Ay, but she'll think that it is spoke in hate.

sp.speaker: PROTEUS
sp.p:
Ay, if his enemy deliver it:
Therefore it must with circumstance be spoken
By one whom she esteemeth as his friend.

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.p: Then you must undertake to slander him.

sp.speaker: PROTEUS
sp.p:
And that, my lord, I shall be loath to do:
'Tis an ill office for a gentleman,
Especially against his very friend.

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.p:
Where your good word cannot advantage him,
Your slander never can endamage him;
Therefore the office is indifferent,
Being entreated to it by your friend.

sp.speaker: PROTEUS
sp.p:
You have prevail'd, my lord; if I can do it
By ought that I can speak in his dispraise,
She shall not long continue love to him.
But say this weed her love from Valentine,
It follows not that she will love Sir Thurio.

sp.speaker: THURIO
sp.p:
Therefore, as you unwind her love from him,
Lest it should ravel and be good to none,
You must provide to bottom it on me;
Which must be done by praising me as much
As you in worth dispraise Sir Valentine.

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.p:
And, Proteus, we dare trust you in this kind,
Because we know, on Valentine's report,
You are already Love's firm votary
And cannot soon revolt and change your mind.
Upon this warrant shall you have access
Where you with Silvia may confer at large;
For she is lumpish, heavy, melancholy,
And, for your friend's sake, will be glad of you;
Where you may temper her by your persuasion
To hate young Valentine and love my friend.

sp.speaker: PROTEUS
sp.p:
As much as I can do, I will effect:
But you, Sir Thurio, are not sharp enough;
You must lay lime to tangle her desires
By wailful sonnets, whose composed rhymes
Should be full-fraught with serviceable vows.

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.p:
Ay,
Much is the force of heaven-bred poesy.

sp.speaker: PROTEUS
sp.p:
Say that upon the altar of her beauty
You sacrifice your tears, your sighs, your heart:
Write till your ink be dry, and with your tears
Moist it again, and frame some feeling line
That may discover such integrity:
For Orpheus' lute was strung with poets' sinews,
Whose golden touch could soften steel and stones,
Make tigers tame and huge leviathans
Forsake unsounded deeps to dance on sands.
After your dire-lamenting elegies,
Visit by night your lady's chamber-window
With some sweet concert; to their instruments
Tune a deploring dump: the night's dead silence
Will well become such sweet-complaining grievance.
This, or else nothing, will inherit her.

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.p: This discipline shows thou hast been in love.

sp.speaker: THURIO
sp.p:
And thy advice this night I'll put in practise.
Therefore, sweet Proteus, my direction-giver,
Let us into the city presently
To sort some gentlemen well skill'd in music.
I have a sonnet that will serve the turn
To give the onset to thy good advice.

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.p: About it, gentlemen!

sp.speaker: PROTEUS
sp.p:
We'll wait upon your grace till after supper,
And afterward determine our proceedings.

sp.speaker: DUKE
sp.p: Even now about it! I will pardon you.

p.stage: The frontiers of Mantua. A forest.

sp.speaker: First Outlaw
sp.p: Fellows, stand fast; I see a passenger.

sp.speaker: Second Outlaw
sp.p: If there be ten, shrink not, but down with 'em.

sp.speaker: Third Outlaw
sp.p:
Stand, sir, and throw us that you have about ye:
If not: we'll make you sit and rifle you.

sp.speaker: SPEED
sp.p:
Sir, we are undone; these are the villains
That all the travellers do fear so much.

sp.speaker: VALENTINE
sp.p: My friends,—

sp.speaker: First Outlaw
sp.p: That's not so, sir: we are your enemies.

sp.speaker: Second Outlaw
sp.p: Peace! we'll hear him.

sp.speaker: Third Outlaw
sp.p: Ay, by my beard, will we, for he's a proper man.

sp.speaker: VALENTINE
sp.p:
Then know that I have little wealth to lose:
A man I am cross'd with adversity;
My riches are these poor habiliments,
Of which if you should here disfurnish me,
You take the sum and substance that I have.

sp.speaker: Second Outlaw
sp.p: Whither travel you?

sp.speaker: VALENTINE
sp.p: To Verona.

sp.speaker: First Outlaw
sp.p: Whence came you?

sp.speaker: VALENTINE
sp.p: From Milan.

sp.speaker: Third Outlaw
sp.p: Have you long sojourned there?

sp.speaker: VALENTINE
sp.p:
Some sixteen months, and longer might have stay'd,
If crooked fortune had not thwarted me.

sp.speaker: First Outlaw
sp.p: What, were you banish'd thence?

sp.speaker: VALENTINE
sp.p: I was.

sp.speaker: Second Outlaw
sp.p: For what offence?

sp.speaker: VALENTINE
sp.p:
For that which now torments me to rehearse:
I kill'd a man, whose death I much repent;
But yet I slew him manfully in fight,
Without false vantage or base treachery.

sp.speaker: First Outlaw
sp.p:
Why, ne'er repent it, if it were done so.
But were you banish'd for so small a fault?

sp.speaker: VALENTINE
sp.p: I was, and held me glad of such a doom.

sp.speaker: Second Outlaw
sp.p: Have you the tongues?

sp.speaker: VALENTINE
sp.p:
My youthful travel therein made me happy,
Or else I often had been miserable.

sp.speaker: Third Outlaw
sp.p:
By the bare scalp of Robin Hood's fat friar,
This fellow were a king for our wild faction!

sp.speaker: First Outlaw
sp.p: We'll have him. Sirs, a word.

sp.speaker: SPEED
sp.p: Master, be one of them; it's an honourable kind of thievery.

sp.speaker: VALENTINE
sp.p: Peace, villain!

sp.speaker: Second Outlaw
sp.p: Tell us this: have you any thing to take to?

sp.speaker: VALENTINE
sp.p: Nothing but my fortune.

sp.speaker: Third Outlaw
sp.p:
Know, then, that some of us are gentlemen,
Such as the fury of ungovern'd youth
Thrust from the company of awful men:
Myself was from Verona banished
For practising to steal away a lady,
An heir, and near allied unto the duke.

sp.speaker: Second Outlaw
sp.p:
And I from Mantua, for a gentleman,
Who, in my mood, I stabb'd unto the heart.

sp.speaker: First Outlaw
sp.p:
And I for such like petty crimes as these,
But to the purpose—for we cite our faults,
That they may hold excus'd our lawless lives;
And partly, seeing you are beautified
With goodly shape and by your own report
A linguist and a man of such perfection
As we do in our quality much want—

sp.speaker: Second Outlaw
sp.p:
Indeed, because you are a banish'd man,
Therefore, above the rest, we parley to you:
Are you content to be our general?
To make a virtue of necessity
And live, as we do, in this wilderness?

sp.speaker: Third Outlaw
sp.p:
What say'st thou? wilt thou be of our consort?
Say ay, and be the captain of us all:
We'll do thee homage and be ruled by thee,
Love thee as our commander and our king.

sp.speaker: First Outlaw
sp.p: But if thou scorn our courtesy, thou diest.

sp.speaker: Second Outlaw
sp.p: Thou shalt not live to brag what we have offer'd.

sp.speaker: VALENTINE
sp.p:
I take your offer and will live with you,
Provided that you do no outrages
On silly women or poor passengers.

sp.speaker: Third Outlaw
sp.p:
No, we detest such vile base practises.
Come, go with us, we'll bring thee to our crews,
And show thee all the treasure we have got,
Which, with ourselves, all rest at thy dispose.

p.stage: Milan. Outside the DUKE's palace, under SILVIA's chamber.

sp.speaker: PROTEUS
sp.p:
Already have I been false to Valentine
And now I must be as unjust to Thurio.
Under the colour of commending him,
I have access my own love to prefer:
But Silvia is too fair, too true, too holy,
To be corrupted with my worthless gifts.
When I protest true loyalty to her,
She twits me with my falsehood to my friend;
When to her beauty I commend my vows,
She bids me think how I have been forsworn
In breaking faith with Julia whom I loved:
And notwithstanding all her sudden quips,
The least whereof would quell a lover's hope,
Yet, spaniel-like, the more she spurns my love,
The more it grows and fawneth on her still.
But here comes Thurio: now must we to her window,
And give some evening music to her ear.

sp.speaker: THURIO
sp.p: How now, Sir Proteus, are you crept before us?

sp.speaker: PROTEUS
sp.p:
Ay, gentle Thurio: for you know that love
Will creep in service where it cannot go.

sp.speaker: THURIO
sp.p: Ay, but I hope, sir, that you love not here.

sp.speaker: PROTEUS
sp.p: Sir, but I do; or else I would be hence.

sp.speaker: THURIO
sp.p: Who? Silvia?

sp.speaker: PROTEUS
sp.p: Ay, Silvia; for your sake.

sp.speaker: THURIO
sp.p:
I thank you for your own. Now, gentlemen,
Let's tune, and to it lustily awhile.

p.stage: Enter, at a distance, Host, and JULIA in boy's clothes

sp.speaker: Host
sp.p:
Now, my young guest, methinks you're allycholly: I
pray you, why is it?

sp.speaker: JULIA
sp.p: Marry, mine host, because I cannot be merry.

sp.speaker: Host
sp.p:
Come, we'll have you merry: I'll bring you where
you shall hear music and see the gentleman that you asked for.

sp.speaker: JULIA
sp.p: But shall I hear him speak?

sp.speaker: Host
sp.p: Ay, that you shall.

sp.speaker: JULIA
sp.p: That will be music.

sp.speaker: Host
sp.p: Hark, hark!

sp.speaker: JULIA
sp.p: Is he among these?

sp.speaker: Host
sp.p:
Ay: but, peace! let's hear 'em.
SONG.
Who is Silvia? what is she,
That all our swains commend her?
Holy, fair and wise is she;
The heaven such grace did lend her,
That she might admired be.
Is she kind as she is fair?
For beauty lives with kindness.
Love doth to her eyes repair,
To help him of his blindness,
And, being help'd, inhabits there.
Then to Silvia let us sing,
That Silvia is excelling;
She excels each mortal thing
Upon the dull earth dwelling:
To her let us garlands bring.

sp.speaker: Host
sp.p:
How now! are you sadder than you were before? How
do you, man? the music likes you not.

sp.speaker: JULIA
